anxiety would suggest thinking about how you feel about everything else going on in your life right now if you find that you re feeling anxious about other things as well really suggest you talk to your doctor postpartum anxiety is the oft neglected sibling of ppd and you do need to suffer had the exact same thing happen when my son was born my husband and discussed names for what seemed like forever and finally decided on one after about months into the pregnancy our daughter had unisex name and we wanted to follow that trend and give our son unisex name as well while his name is definitely boy name it not the most masculine name out there assumed he would be born weighing about pounds like his sister had so did think too much about his name not fitting him in those terms when he was born at 12 pounds had three distinctive thoughts there is my beautiful baby boy holy crap that kid is huge oh no we have chosen the wrong name to me he did look like the name we had chosen for him in the slightest and it gnawed at me asked everyone what they thought and everyone tentatively agreed that he did really match his name because he was born so big and brawny like he should have been named bruno or something hyper masculine also because we had already told virtually everyone in the world his name before he had even graced us with his presence felt foolish to back peddle and name him something different at the time of his birth silly notion of course he could have gone by his middle name as it would have suited him or even his first and middle initials but hated that idea was terrified this kid would grow up with complex about his name or identity and he would never forgive his mother for her indecisiveness or at the very least her inability to chose decent name for her son obviously that is an over exaggeration but in my mind at the time was so scared that had somehow started the wheels of some awful life long identity crisis in reality my son is now almost two and he fits his name to tee could not imagine him as anything else but the name that had so painstakingly agonised over my point is that it is ultimately up to you whether or not you can imagine your son with the name you had chosen for him but as someone who has been there am very happy that stuck with my son original name your son is gorgeous by the way and think that he definitely could be roman this may not be true for your baby but thought throw it out there my besties baby is biracial she white and the daddy is hispanic when her son liam was born he looked really pale and light
